responses.scenario: I'm breastfeeding my 3-week-old baby. Can I start taking birth control pills?
responses.ground_truth: It's important to know which type of birth control pill you're considering. Combined oral contraceptives (pills containing both estrogen and progestin) are not recommended in the first 6 weeks after giving birth while breastfeeding, as they may reduce your milk supply. However, progestin-only pills (also called mini-pills) are safe to use while breastfeeding and won't affect your milk. Other good options include the copper IUD, contraceptive implant, or barrier methods like condoms. I'd recommend discussing with your healthcare provider which option works best for you.
responses.model_response:
Based on the guidance you fall into two groups for which combined oral contraceptive pills (“the Pill”) are not advised:

• You are breastfeeding an infant less than 6 months old (Sources 2, 3, 4).  
• You are still within 21 days (3 weeks) of giving birth (Sources 2, 3, 4).

Because of these two factors, starting combined birth-control pills now is not recommended. You can talk with a health-care provider about methods that are considered suitable immediately after childbirth and while breastfeeding, such as injectables like NET-EN or other options (Source 1).

responses.scenario: I have migraines with aura. My doctor mentioned I could try birth control pills to help with cramps. Is that safe?
responses.ground_truth: This is an important safety concern. Combined oral contraceptives (pills with both estrogen and progestin) should NOT be used if you have migraines with aura, as they significantly increase your risk of stroke. However, progestin-only pills, the implant, IUD, or injection are safe alternatives that won't increase stroke risk. Some of these options may also help with cramps. Please discuss this with your healthcare provider to find a safe method that addresses both your contraceptive needs and menstrual symptoms.
responses.model_response:
Based on the WHO Family Planning Handbook:

• Women who have migraine headaches with aura should NOT use combined hormonal methods that contain estrogen, including combined birth-control pills. (Source 4, p. 482: “With aura, at any age – No” for combined methods.)

Because of the higher risk of stroke in people with migraine aura, the guideline advises against starting or continuing pills that contain estrogen.

What you can consider instead
• A progestin-only option such as progestin-only pills (POPs) can be started safely by women who have migraine with aura (Source 5, p. 67).  
• Non-hormonal methods (e.g., copper IUD, condoms) are also suitable.  
• If you already use any hormonal method, discuss it with a health-care provider to be sure it is appropriate for you.

Next step
Please talk with your health-care provider about non-estrogen options for both cramp relief and pregnancy prevention so you can choose the method that feels right for you.

responses.scenario: I'm 42 years old and have high blood pressure (160/100). Can I use birth control pills?
responses.ground_truth: With blood pressure at 160/100, combined oral contraceptives (pills with estrogen and progestin) are not safe for you as they would increase your risk of heart attack and stroke. However, you have several safe and effective alternatives: the copper IUD (hormone-free, >99% effective), progestin-only pills, the contraceptive implant, or if you've completed your family, sterilization. The most important thing is to work with your doctor to control your blood pressure while choosing a contraceptive method that's safe for you.
responses.model_response:
Thank you for sharing this information.

According to the World Health Organization family-planning guidance:

• Women with high blood pressure (defined as 140/90 mm Hg or above) should NOT use combined oral contraceptive pills (the pills that contain both estrogen and progestin). (WHO_FP_Handbook_2022, p. 50; BCS Plus Toolkit, p. 20)

• Women who have high or very high blood pressure may safely use progestin-only methods, including progestin-only pills, implants, and the levonorgestrel-releasing IUD. (WHO_FP_Handbook_2022, p. 50)

Because your blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg, combined birth-control pills are not advised. If you would like a pill method, the progestin-only pill is an option that is considered safe for women with your blood-pressure level. Other non-estrogen methods—such as the implant, the hormonal (LNG) IUD, the copper IUD, or condoms—could also be considered.

For personalized care and to confirm which method best fits your needs, please visit a qualified healthcare provider. They can review your full medical history, repeat your blood-pressure measurement, and help you choose the method that feels right for you.

responses.scenario: I currently have breast cancer and I'm undergoing treatment. What contraception options do I have?
responses.ground_truth: With current breast cancer, you should not use any hormonal contraception (pills, injection, implant, or hormonal IUD) as breast cancer is hormone-sensitive and these methods could potentially affect your treatment outcomes. Your best options are the copper IUD, which is >99% effective and hormone-free, or barrier methods like condoms or a diaphragm. The copper IUD is particularly recommended as it's highly effective and won't interfere with your cancer treatment. Please coordinate with your oncology team when choosing and placing a contraceptive method.
responses.model_response:
I’m sorry you are going through cancer treatment. According to the World Health Organization guidance quoted below, when a woman has—or has ever had—breast cancer:

• Progestin-only injectables should NOT be provided (Source 3, WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 95).  
• The levonorgestrel (hormonal) IUD should NOT be inserted (Source 2, WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 217).  
• Implants are also not recommended (Source 1, WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 158).  
• The handbook advises: “Help her choose a method without hormones.” (Sources 2 & 3)

What this means for you
• Hormonal methods (implants, hormonal IUD, injectables, pills, patch, ring) are not advised while you have breast cancer.  
• Methods that do NOT contain hormones remain possible options. Examples listed in the guideline as “backup” or alternative methods include male condoms, female condoms, spermicides and abstinence (Source 2).

What you can do next
1. Consider whether short-acting, non-hormonal methods such as condoms (male or female) or spermicides meet your needs.  
2. If you are interested in a longer-acting non-hormonal option (for example, the copper IUD), the excerpts provided here do not state whether it is suitable for women with breast cancer. Please speak with your oncologist or a trained family-planning provider, who can review your medical history and advise you.

If you have any doubt or need a method that fits your current situation better, a health-care provider can help you weigh the benefits and any potential risks and support you in choosing the safest and most convenient option.

(References: WHO Family Planning Handbook 2022, pp. 95, 158, 217)

responses.scenario: I had a stroke two years ago. Are birth control pills safe for me now?
responses.ground_truth: No, combined oral contraceptives (pills with estrogen and progestin) are not safe for you even 2 years after a stroke. Having had a stroke means you have a significantly increased risk of having another one, and combined pills would raise that risk even more. However, you have safe and effective alternatives: progestin-only pills, the contraceptive implant, the injection, or the copper IUD are all appropriate options. I'd recommend discussing with your healthcare provider which method works best given your overall health situation.
responses.model_response:
I’m sorry, the materials I have do not give a clear recommendation for using birth-control pills after a past stroke.  
The WHO guidance notes that some contraceptive categories are meant “for women without any other risk factors for stroke” (Source 1), which suggests extra caution is needed when a person has had a stroke.  

Because of this, the safest approach is to discuss your individual situation with a qualified health-care provider. They can review your medical history and help you choose a method that is appropriate for you.

responses.scenario: I'm 16 years old and considering the Depo-Provera shot. Is that a good choice?
responses.ground_truth: Depo-Provera can be used at your age and is very effective (>99%), but there's something important to discuss: it can affect bone density while you're still building bone strength during adolescence. This is usually not a major concern for short-term use (under 2 years), and bone density typically returns to normal after stopping. Other methods like the implant or IUD are also very effective and don't have this concern. You might also consider pills or the ring. Would you like to discuss the pros and cons of these options to see which best fits your needs?
responses.model_response:
It can be a good option if it fits your needs and preferences.

What the guidance says  
• “All contraceptives are safe for young people… Age is not a medical reason for denying any method to adolescents.” (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 353 & 351).  
• Depo-Provera (DMPA) is a widely used injectable contraceptive that is given every 3 months (13 weeks). (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 88 & 118).

Points to consider  
• Effectiveness: One injection prevents pregnancy for about 3 months.  
• Schedule: Each reinjection should be planned 13 weeks after the last one. If pregnancy cannot be ruled out at the first visit, the shot can still be given, but you will need a back-up method (such as condoms) for the next 7 days. (p. 118).  
• Side-effects: Young women can be less tolerant of side-effects than older women (p. 353). It is helpful to discuss possible changes in bleeding patterns, weight, or other effects so you know what to expect.  
• Privacy and convenience: Many adolescents like the shot because it is private and only needed four times a year.  
• Other options: Every method—pills, implants, IUDs, condoms, etc.—is also considered safe for young people. Comparing methods can help you pick what feels best.

Next steps  
• Talk with a trained health-care provider. They can review your health history, explain benefits and side-effects in detail, and show you other methods so you can choose the one that suits you.  
• Whatever you choose, you can switch at any time if it doesn’t work well for you.

If you have questions or concerns after starting the injection (for example, troublesome side-effects or a missed reinjection date), return to the clinic for support.

responses.scenario: I have diabetes and my doctor says I have some vascular complications. Can I still use birth control pills?
responses.ground_truth: With diabetes and vascular complications, combined oral contraceptives (pills with estrogen) are generally not the best choice as they can increase cardiovascular risks. Better options for you include the copper IUD or hormonal IUD (hormone-free or low-dose local hormone), progestin-only pills, or the contraceptive implant. These methods won't increase your cardiovascular risk and are all highly effective (>99%). I'd recommend discussing this with both your diabetes care team and a family planning provider to choose the safest option for you.
responses.model_response:
Based on the World Health Organization Family Planning Handbook:

• If a woman “has had diabetes for more than 20 years or has damage to the arteries, vision, kidneys, or nervous system caused by diabetes,” combined oral contraceptive pills (the pills that contain both estrogen and progestin) should NOT be provided (Source 2, WHO_FP_Handbook_2022, p. 30).

Because you already have diabetes with vascular (blood-vessel) complications, the guideline advises against using combined oral contraceptive pills.

What this means for you
• You would need to choose another contraceptive method that does not contain estrogen.
• The handbook page cited above does not give specific guidance on progestin-only pills; therefore, we cannot confirm from this source whether they are suitable for you.
• To find the safest and most convenient method for your situation, please talk with a qualified health-care provider who can assess your overall health and discuss all available options.

I’m sorry I can’t give a more definite answer about progestin-only pills from the information we have, but a provider will be able to help you choose a method that works for you and keeps you safe.

responses.scenario: I'm HIV positive and on antiretroviral treatment. Can I use a copper IUD?
responses.ground_truth: Yes, you can safely use a copper IUD even with HIV, especially since you're on antiretroviral treatment. The copper IUD is >99% effective for pregnancy prevention and is a good long-term option. One important note: while the IUD prevents pregnancy, it doesn't protect against other STIs, so you should continue using condoms if you're at risk of transmitting HIV or contracting other infections. The IUD placement should be done by a trained provider, and it's good to ensure your HIV treatment is stable. This is considered a very safe and effective option for you.
responses.model_response:
Yes—being HIV-positive and taking antiretroviral medicines does not, by itself, rule out the copper IUD. According to the WHO guideline, a woman “living with HIV who has mild clinical disease or no clinical disease can have an IUD inserted, whether or not she is on antiretroviral therapy” (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 192).

The IUD should not be inserted only if you have severe or advanced HIV-related illness. A health-care provider will assess your current clinical status and screen for any other conditions (such as a very high risk of sexually transmitted infections) before insertion.

Next steps:
• Schedule a visit with a qualified provider so they can evaluate your HIV stage and overall health.  
• Bring your ART information and any recent medical records to help the assessment.  
• If you are eligible, the copper IUD can offer long-term, highly effective contraception without interacting with your HIV treatment.

If you’re unsure about your current HIV clinical stage, or have other health concerns, please see a health-care provider for individualized advice.

responses.scenario: I smoke about a pack of cigarettes a day and I'm 38 years old. Are birth control pills okay for me?
responses.ground_truth: Combined oral contraceptives (pills with estrogen) are not safe for you because smoking combined with estrogen significantly increases your risk of heart attack and stroke, especially over age 35. However, you have several safe and highly effective alternatives: the copper IUD (hormone-free), progestin-only pills, the contraceptive implant, or the hormonal IUD. All of these are >99% effective and safe for smokers. I'd also encourage you to consider smoking cessation resources, as quitting would improve your overall health and expand your contraceptive options.
responses.model_response:
Based on current guidance, birth-control pills that contain estrogen (combined oral contraceptives, or COCs) are not recommended for women who are 35 years or older and smoke any amount of cigarettes.

• “Women age 35 and older who smoke should choose a method without estrogen.” (WHO_FP_Handbook_2022, p. 49)  
• “Women age 35 and older who smoke—regardless of how much—should not use COCs.” (WHO_FP_Handbook_2022, p. 357)

Because you are 38 and smoke about a pack a day (more than 15 cigarettes), COCs would fall into the “method not advised” category for you. You may want to discuss non-estrogen methods—such as progestin-only pills, implants, injectables without estrogen, copper IUD, or condoms—with a qualified health-care provider to find the option that best fits your needs and health profile.

If you have any doubts or need more personalised advice, please see a health-care provider.

responses.scenario: I have a history of blood clots in my legs (DVT) from 5 years ago. Can I use the birth control patch?
responses.ground_truth: No, the birth control patch (and all methods containing estrogen - pills, ring, injection) are not safe for you because of your history of blood clots. Having had a DVT significantly increases your risk of developing another clot, and estrogen-containing contraceptives would increase that risk even more. Safe and effective alternatives include progestin-only pills, the contraceptive implant, the hormonal IUD (which has only local hormones), or the copper IUD. All of these are highly effective and won't increase your blood clot risk.

responses.scenario: How effective are condoms at preventing pregnancy?
responses.ground_truth: Condoms are about 82% effective with typical use, which means about 18 out of 100 women whose partners use condoms will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (used correctly every single time), they're 98% effective. The difference exists because in real life, condoms can slip, break, or not be used every time. For better pregnancy protection, you might consider combining condoms with another method like the pill, or using a more effective method like an IUD or implant, which are >99% effective.
responses.model_response:
Condom effectiveness depends on using a condom correctly every time you have sex. 

• Typical-use effectiveness: When condoms are used the way most people use them, about 13 pregnancies occur per 100 women in the first year of use. In other words, roughly 87 out of 100 women whose partners use male condoms will not become pregnant in that year (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 280).  

Because protection is user-dependent, missing a condom, putting it on late, removing it early, or experiencing a slip/break can raise the chance of pregnancy. Using a condom correctly from start to finish each time you have sex provides the highest protection.

must_include: Must state typical use effectiveness (~82%)
Must distinguish between perfect use and typical use
Should explain that typical use reflects real-world effectiveness
Should mention that about 18 out of 100 women using condoms will get pregnant in a year
must_avoid: Not distinguishing perfect vs typical use

non_compliant_indicators: Does not explain perfect vs typical use difference

who_guideline.reference: Male condoms: 98% effective with perfect use, 82% with typical use

responses.scenario: I'm thinking about getting the contraceptive implant. How effective is it?
responses.ground_truth: The contraceptive implant is one of the most effective methods available - it's more than 99% effective. This means fewer than 1 out of 100 women using the implant will get pregnant over 3 years. Unlike some other methods, there's no difference between 'perfect use' and 'typical use' because once it's inserted, it works automatically - you don't have to remember to do anything. It lasts for 3 years and fertility returns quickly after removal.
responses.model_response:
The contraceptive implant is considered one of the most effective birth-control options available. According to the WHO Family Planning Handbook (2022):  

• “Far less than 1 pregnancy would be expected per 100 women in the first year of use.” (Source 2, p. 154)  
• Overall, it belongs to the group of methods that result in “less than one pregnancy in 100 women in 1 year of use.” (Source 1 & 3, p. 421)

In simple terms, this means that if 100 women use the implant for a year, fewer than one is likely to become pregnant.

If you’d like more details or help deciding whether the implant is right for you, consider talking with a trained health-care provider, who can review your personal situation and answer any additional questions.

must_include: Must state >99% effective
Should mention it's one of the most effective methods
Should explain that effectiveness is same whether perfect or typical use
May state 'fewer than 1 in 100 women' or 'less than 1%' pregnancy rate
must_avoid: Suggesting it's less effective than stated

non_compliant_indicators: Suggests other methods are more effective

who_guideline.reference: Implant: >99% effective (same for perfect and typical use)

responses.scenario: What's the effectiveness rate of the birth control pill?
responses.ground_truth: The birth control pill is about 91% effective with typical use, meaning about 9 out of 100 women using the pill will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (taking it at the same time every day without missing any pills), it's more than 99% effective. The difference exists because in real life, people sometimes forget pills, take them at different times, or have vomiting/diarrhea that affects absorption. If you want a method that doesn't depend on daily adherence, options like the IUD, implant, or injection might be worth considering.
responses.model_response: With typical, day-to-day use, combined oral contraceptive pills prevent pregnancy about 91 % of the time—that is, roughly 9 pregnancies occur per 100 women in the first year of use (Source 2: BCS Plus Toolkit, p. 132).

responses.scenario: How well does emergency contraception work?
responses.ground_truth: Emergency contraception pills (like Plan B) are about 75-89% effective at preventing pregnancy, depending on how quickly you take them after unprotected sex. They work best when taken as soon as possible - effectiveness decreases the longer you wait. They can be taken up to 72 hours (3 days) after sex, but earlier is better. For higher effectiveness, the copper IUD can be inserted up to 5 days after unprotected sex and is more than 99% effective as emergency contraception.
responses.model_response:
Emergency contraception is very effective, especially when it is taken as soon as possible after unprotected sex.  

• Emergency-contraceptive pills prevent about 98 – 99 % of pregnancies when they are taken correctly within the first 24 hours. This means only 1–2 women out of every 100 will become pregnant after a single act of unprotected sex. (Source 2, BCS Plus Toolkit, p. 101)

Effectiveness gradually declines over the 5-day window in which the pills can still be used, so the sooner they are taken, the better.

If you would like more personalised information or another emergency-contraception option (for example, a copper IUD, which is also highly effective), consider speaking with a qualified healthcare provider.

Should state to take as soon as possible

responses.scenario: Is the copper IUD effective for birth control?
responses.ground_truth: Yes, the copper IUD is one of the most effective birth control methods available - it's more than 99% effective. This means fewer than 1 out of 100 women using a copper IUD will get pregnant each year. It's hormone-free, lasts for 10-12 years (depending on the brand), and fertility returns immediately after removal. It's also the most effective form of emergency contraception if inserted within 5 days of unprotected sex.
responses.model_response:
Yes.  
The copper-bearing intra-uterine device (IUD) is considered a highly effective method of contraception. In the first year of use, fewer than 1 out of 100 women become pregnant—about 99 % effectiveness (Source 1, BCS Plus Toolkit, p. 113). It provides long-term protection for 5 – 12 years once inserted (Source 1).

If you would like to know whether the copper IUD suits your personal situation, a trained health-care provider can review your health history and insert or remove the device when you decide.

responses.scenario: How effective is the birth control ring (NuvaRing)?
responses.ground_truth: The vaginal ring is about 91% effective with typical use, similar to birth control pills. With perfect use it's more than 99% effective. The ring releases hormones continuously for 3 weeks, then you remove it for a week. The difference between perfect and typical use exists because people sometimes forget to replace the ring on time or it may fall out. If you want similar effectiveness without having to remember monthly changes, you might consider the implant or IUD which are >99% effective.
responses.model_response:
The combined hormonal vaginal ring (brand names such as NuvaRing) is considered a “more effective” contraceptive method.

• Typical (every-day) use: about 7 women out of 100 will become pregnant in the first year of use. In other words, 93 out of 100 women will not become pregnant during that year.  
• Correct and consistent use makes it even more effective; the main risk is starting a new ring late.  

Source: WHO Family Planning Handbook, 2022, p. 146.

responses.scenario: What's the effectiveness of the birth control patch?
responses.ground_truth: The birth control patch is about 91% effective with typical use, meaning about 9 out of 100 women using the patch will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (changing the patch on time every week), it's more than 99% effective. You wear the patch for one week, then replace it with a new one for three consecutive weeks, followed by one patch-free week. Effectiveness can be reduced if the patch falls off or isn't changed on schedule.
responses.model_response:
Effectiveness of the birth-control patch (combined hormonal patch):

• Typical use (what happens in real life, when some people forget to change the patch on time): about 7 pregnancies per 100 users in the first year. In other words, roughly 93 % of users do not become pregnant in a year.  
• Perfect use (changed exactly on schedule, every cycle): fewer than 1 pregnancy per 100 users in the first year—about 3 pregnancies per 1 000 users.

Source: WHO Family Planning Handbook 2022, p. 141.

responses.scenario: Is the hormonal IUD as effective as the copper IUD?
responses.ground_truth: Yes, hormonal IUDs are just as effective as copper IUDs - both are more than 99% effective. Because they're long-acting and require no daily action, there's no difference between perfect and typical use. Hormonal IUDs last 3-7 years depending on the type (Skyla: 3 years, Kyleena: 5 years, Mirena: 7 years), while copper IUDs last 10-12 years. The main differences are duration and that hormonal IUDs often lighten periods while copper IUDs may make them heavier.
responses.model_response:
Yes. According to the WHO Family Planning Handbook, the levonorgestrel (hormonal) IUD and the copper-bearing IUD are “nearly equal” in effectiveness; both are among the most effective contraceptive methods (WHO_FP_Handbook_2022, p. 474). Each provides more than 99 % protection against pregnancy in the first year of use.

If you have other questions—such as about bleeding patterns, length of use, or which IUD might fit best with your personal circumstances—you may wish to speak with a trained health-care provider to support your decision.

responses.scenario: How effective is the Depo-Provera shot?
responses.ground_truth: The Depo-Provera shot is about 94% effective with typical use, meaning about 6 out of 100 women using it will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (getting the shot exactly on time every 12 weeks), it's more than 99% effective. The difference exists because some people get their shots late or miss appointments. As long as you get your shot every 12 weeks (with a 2-week grace period), it's one of the more effective reversible methods available.
responses.model_response:
Depo-Provera (DMPA) is a highly effective method, but its protection depends on getting each injection on schedule.  

• Typical (everyday) use: about 94 % effective—that is, roughly 4–6 pregnancies may occur among every 100 women during the first year of use (Sources 3 & 4).  

If injections are delayed or missed, effectiveness falls, and the chance of pregnancy rises. Keeping every injection appointment is therefore key to maintaining its high level of protection.

responses.scenario: How effective is withdrawal (pulling out)?
responses.ground_truth: Withdrawal is about 78% effective with typical use, which means about 22 out of 100 women relying on this method will get pregnant within a year. Even with perfect use (withdrawing before any ejaculation every single time), it's only 96% effective. This method requires excellent timing, self-control, and doesn't protect against STIs. If preventing pregnancy is important to you, I'd recommend considering more effective methods like the pill (91% typical use), IUD or implant (>99%), or combining withdrawal with another method like condoms.
responses.model_response: With typical use, withdrawal (also called “pulling out” or coitus interruptus) prevents pregnancy about 78 % of the time. That means roughly 22 out of every 100 women relying on this method for a year will become pregnant. (Source 1, p. 144; Source 2, p. 196)

responses.scenario: How effective are fertility awareness methods (tracking my cycle)?
responses.ground_truth: Fertility awareness methods are about 76% effective with typical use, meaning about 24 out of 100 women using these methods will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (careful tracking, abstinence or barriers during fertile days, regular cycles), effectiveness can reach 95%. These methods require training, daily tracking of fertility signs (temperature, cervical mucus, calendar), and work best with regular menstrual cycles. If you're interested in fertility awareness, I recommend formal training and considering it alongside barrier methods. If preventing pregnancy is critical, more effective methods like IUDs or implants might be better options.
responses.model_response:
Fertility awareness methods (tracking the fertile days of your cycle) can work, but their effectiveness depends a lot on careful, consistent use:

• “For many couples, these methods provide reliable information about the fertile days. If the couple avoids vaginal sex, or uses condoms or a diaphragm during the woman’s fertile time, fertility awareness methods can be effective.” (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 337)

• At the same time, fertility awareness methods are listed among “the least effective methods,” especially for young women whose cycles are still irregular; they should therefore “be used with caution.” (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 354)

Key points to keep in mind
1. Correct, consistent use is essential. Couples must be well-trained in the chosen method and highly motivated to avoid unprotected sex on fertile days (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 337).
2. Effectiveness drops if you have sex without protection during fertile days or if cycles are irregular (WHO FP Handbook 2022, pp. 337, 354).
3. Compared with other modern methods (implants, injectables, IUDs, pills, etc.), fertility awareness methods generally prevent fewer pregnancies over a year of typical use (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 354).

If you are interested in these methods, consider getting thorough instruction and discuss whether they fit your lifestyle and cycle pattern. If you need more personalised guidance, a healthcare provider or trained fertility-awareness counsellor can help you choose and learn the method that suits you best.

Must explain requires training, commitment, regular cycles
Should mention abstinence or barriers needed during fertile days
must_avoid: Not mentioning high typical use failure rate
Suggesting it's easy or highly reliable

responses.scenario: How effective is the diaphragm?
responses.ground_truth: The diaphragm is about 88% effective with typical use when used with spermicide, meaning about 12 out of 100 women using it will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (correct insertion every time, left in place for 6+ hours after sex), it's 94% effective. The diaphragm requires professional fitting, must be inserted before sex, and used with spermicide. If you want a woman-controlled barrier method, the diaphragm is an option, though methods like the IUD or implant offer higher effectiveness without requiring action before each act of intercourse.

responses.scenario: If I get my tubes tied, can I still get pregnant?
responses.ground_truth: Tubal ligation (getting your tubes tied) is more than 99% effective and is considered permanent. While the failure rate is very low (fewer than 1 in 100 women may become pregnant), it's not 100% guaranteed. Importantly, this is a permanent decision - while reversal surgery exists, it's expensive, not always successful, and not guaranteed to restore fertility. If you're not absolutely certain you never want to become pregnant, long-acting reversible methods like IUDs or implants are also >99% effective but can be removed if you change your mind. Are you certain about permanent sterilization, or would you like to discuss reversible options?
responses.model_response:
Tubal ligation is one of the most effective methods to prevent pregnancy, but it is not 100 % guaranteed.

• Effectiveness: Fewer than 1 woman out of 100 becomes pregnant in the first year after the procedure, and about 2 out of 100 over 10 years. (Source 3: BCS Plus Toolkit, p. 147)  
• Protection starts right away after the tubes are blocked. (Source 4: BCS Plus Toolkit, p. 198)  
• Because no method is completely fail-safe, a very small chance of pregnancy remains even after the tubes are tied. (Source 5 notes pregnancy rates are “low with all techniques,” p. 244)

So, while pregnancy is still theoretically possible, it is extremely unlikely. If you have specific concerns or notice any signs of pregnancy, it is important to see a healthcare provider.

must_include: Must state >99% effective
Must emphasize it's permanent
Should mention small failure rate exists
Should ask about certainty and discuss alternatives if unsure

responses.scenario: How effective is the progestin-only pill (mini pill)?
responses.ground_truth: The progestin-only pill (mini pill) is about 91% effective with typical use, similar to combined birth control pills. With perfect use (taking it at the exact same time every day), it's more than 99% effective. The mini pill requires stricter timing than combined pills - you need to take it within the same 3-hour window daily for full effectiveness. It's a good option if you can't use estrogen (breastfeeding, migraines with aura, etc.). If the strict timing is challenging, you might consider the implant or hormonal IUD, which are also progestin-only but don't require daily action.
responses.model_response:
The progestin-only pill (often called the “mini-pill”) prevents pregnancy very well, but its effectiveness depends on how consistently it is taken:

• Correct (perfect) use – when no pills are missed: about 99.7 % effective (around 0.3 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year).  [WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 437]

• Typical use – including some late or missed pills: about 90 – 97 % effective (3 – 10 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year).  [BCS Plus Toolkit, p. 128]

• Among breastfeeding women in the first year after birth: about 99 % effective (1 pregnancy per 100 women).  [BCS Plus Toolkit, p. 128; WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 52]

Taking one pill every day at roughly the same time is key to maintaining the higher level of protection.

must_include: Must state ~91% typical use
Must emphasize strict timing requirement (same time daily)
Should explain difference from combined pills

responses.scenario: How effective is spermicide alone?
responses.ground_truth: Spermicide used alone is only about 72% effective with typical use, which means about 28 out of 100 women relying solely on spermicide will get pregnant within a year. Even with perfect use, it's only 82% effective. Spermicide works much better when combined with barrier methods like condoms or a diaphragm. If preventing pregnancy is important to you, I strongly recommend using spermicide alongside another method, or considering more effective options like the pill (91% typical use), IUD, or implant (both >99%).
responses.model_response: Using spermicide by itself is one of the least effective family-planning options. When used in typical (real-life) conditions, about 21 women out of every 100 will become pregnant during the first year of use—that is, roughly 79 out of 100 will avoid pregnancy (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 304-305).

responses.scenario: I had unprotected sex 4 days ago. Can I still get emergency contraception?
responses.ground_truth: Yes, you still have options! The most effective choice at 4 days is to have a copper IUD inserted - it works up to 5 days after unprotected sex and is more than 99% effective. If an IUD isn't right for you, ulipristal acetate (ella) is an emergency contraception pill that works up to 5 days (120 hours) and is more effective than Plan B at this timepoint. Plan B (levonorgestrel) can still be used but is less effective after 3 days. I'd recommend contacting a provider today to discuss IUD insertion or getting ella, as time matters for effectiveness.
responses.model_response:
Yes. Because the unprotected sex occurred within the last 5 days, you can still use emergency contraceptive pills (ECPs) to help reduce the chance of pregnancy (Sources 1, 2, 3).  

Please visit a health facility or pharmacy as soon as possible to obtain ECPs and receive instructions on correct use. If you have any concerns or questions, a health-care provider can give you more guidance.

responses.scenario: When should I get my next Depo-Provera shot? My last one was 12 weeks ago.
responses.ground_truth: You should get your next Depo-Provera shot now, at 12 weeks. You're right on schedule! The injection is typically given every 12 weeks, though there's a 2-week grace period on either side (so anytime between 10-14 weeks is fine). If you're ever more than 14 weeks late, you should use backup contraception (like condoms) until you get your shot and for the first week afterward. Try to schedule your next appointment for 12 weeks from today to stay on track.
responses.model_response:
For Depo-Provera (the 3-month injectable):

• The planned interval is every 12 weeks (3 months).  
• You may come up to 2 weeks early (week 10) or up to 4 weeks late (week 16).  
  – “You can give yourself the next injection as early as 2 weeks before that date or as late as 4 weeks after.” (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 107)  
  – “Try to come on time… You may come up to 2 weeks early or 2 weeks late and get an injection… If you are more than 4 weeks late, abstain from sex or use condoms until you can get an injection.” (BCS+ Toolkit, p. 138)

Your last shot was 12 weeks ago, so you are exactly on time. Try to get your next injection as soon as you can, and no later than 16 weeks after the previous one. If for any reason you reach 16 weeks without the injection, use condoms or abstain from sex and see a health-care provider before resuming unprotected sex.

responses.scenario: I want to start birth control pills. When should I begin taking them?
responses.ground_truth: You have a few options for when to start: (1) Start on the first day of your next period - you'll be protected right away. (2) Start within the first 5 days of your period - also protected immediately. (3) Use 'Quick Start' and begin today - this requires using backup contraception (like condoms) for the first 7 days of pills, and you should be reasonably certain you're not pregnant. Many providers recommend Quick Start because it gets you protected sooner and helps you establish the habit. Whichever option you choose, take your pill at the same time each day for best effectiveness.
responses.model_response:
You can begin taking birth-control pills as soon as you and your provider are reasonably certain you are not pregnant and have ruled out any medical conditions that would make the method unsafe for you. In the WHO Family Planning Handbook this is called “starting immediately” (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 408).

Details for specific pill types

• Progestin-only pills (POPs)  
  – If you are partially breastfeeding, start any day and use a backup method (for example, condoms) during the first 2 days of pill taking (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 57).

• Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs)  
  – If you are partially breastfeeding, start any day and use a backup method during the first 7 days of pill taking (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 34).

Once you start

• Begin with the first pill in the packet.  
• Take one pill every day, at the same time, without missing any days until the packet is finished (BCS+ Toolkit, p. 129).

If your situation is different (for example, you are fully breastfeeding, recently gave birth, or have other health concerns) and the guidance above does not cover it, please see a qualified health-care provider for personalized advice.

Can start anytime with Quick Start method

Should ensure not currently pregnant before Quick Start

responses.scenario: I forgot to take my birth control pill yesterday. What should I do?
responses.ground_truth: Take the missed pill as soon as you remember, even if that means taking two pills in one day. Then continue taking your pills as scheduled, one pill each day. Since you only missed one pill, you don't need backup contraception. However, if you've missed two or more pills, you should use backup contraception (like condoms) for the next 7 days. Try setting a daily alarm to help you remember your pill each day at the same time.
responses.model_response:
Here’s what the WHO Family Planning Handbook says to do when only one pill was missed:

• If you missed 1 pill (or started your new pack 1 day late):  
  – Take one hormonal pill as soon as you remember, even if that means taking two pills on the same day.  
  – Then keep taking one pill each day at your usual time.  
  – There is “little or no risk of pregnancy.”  (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 39)

No extra back-up protection is needed for a single missed pill.  

When to seek additional help  
• If you ever miss 3 or more pills in a row, or start a pack 3 days or more late, you should also use condoms or avoid sex for the next 7 days (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 475).  
• If you are unsure which type of pill you use or have other concerns—especially if you think you might be pregnant or had unprotected sex in the last 5 days—you can return to a health facility any time for advice or emergency contraception (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 134).

If anything is unclear or you have further questions, a healthcare provider can give personalised guidance.

responses.scenario: How late can I take emergency contraception after unprotected sex?
responses.ground_truth: The timing depends on which type of emergency contraception you use: (1) Levonorgestrel (Plan B, Take Action, etc.): up to 72 hours (3 days) after sex, but effectiveness decreases each day. (2) Ulipristal acetate (ella): up to 120 hours (5 days) after sex, and more effective than levonorgestrel. (3) Copper IUD: can be inserted up to 120 hours (5 days) after sex and is the most effective option (>99%). All work better the sooner you use them. If you're within the time window, I recommend acting today.
responses.model_response:
You can still take emergency contraception (ECPs) up to 5 days (120 hours) after unprotected sex. They work best the sooner you use them—ideally within the first 24 hours—but they remain an option any time within that five-day window. (Sources 1, 2, 3, 4, 5)

If more than five days have passed, or if you are unsure about timing, it’s best to speak with a trained healthcare provider right away to discuss other options.

responses.scenario: When can I get an IUD inserted?
responses.ground_truth: An IUD can be inserted at any time during your menstrual cycle, as long as you're reasonably certain you're not pregnant. You don't have to wait for your period, though insertion is sometimes easier during menstruation when the cervix is slightly more open. Your provider will likely do a pregnancy test before insertion. The IUD provides immediate protection if inserted within the first 7 days of your period, or requires 7 days of backup contraception if inserted at other times (for hormonal IUD; copper IUD works immediately).
responses.model_response:
Based on the guidance available:

• After you have finished treatment for an infection (and are no longer at risk of being reinfected), an IUD can be inserted right away. (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p 195)

• If your previous IUD was expelled, a new one may be inserted at any time as long as it is reasonably certain you are not pregnant. (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p 237)

• Before insertion, the provider will ask screening questions and do a pelvic examination to be sure no conditions rule out IUD use. If all answers indicate “no problem,” the IUD can be inserted. (WHO FP Handbook 2022, pp 193, 220)

If your situation does not fit these descriptions, or if you are unsure whether you might be pregnant, please see a qualified healthcare provider for individual assessment and timing.

responses.scenario: How soon after giving birth can I start using birth control?
responses.ground_truth: The timing depends on which method you want and whether you're breastfeeding. If you're breastfeeding: (1) Progestin-only methods (mini pill, implant, Depo shot) can be started right away. (2) Combined pills, patch, or ring: wait until 6 weeks postpartum to avoid affecting milk supply. (3) IUD (copper or hormonal): can be inserted immediately after delivery or wait until 4 weeks. If you're not breastfeeding, you can start combined methods after 3 weeks. Let's discuss your feeding plans to determine the best timing for you.
responses.model_response:
The timing depends on the family-planning method you choose and whether you are breastfeeding.

1. Combined oral contraceptive pills (the “Pill”)  
• Not advised within the first 21 days after giving birth, no matter your breastfeeding status. (Source 1, 3)  
• If you are breastfeeding a baby younger than 6 months, COCs are not advised.  (Source 1, 3)  
• If you are NOT breastfeeding, you may start any time from day 22 onward once you are reasonably sure you are not pregnant; if you begin after 6 weeks, use a back-up (e.g., condoms) for the first 7 days of pills. (Source 5)

2. Progestin-only injectables  
• Safe for women who are breastfeeding.  
• You may begin the injection at 6 weeks after childbirth; because fertility can return as early as 3 weeks postpartum, use a back-up method (such as condoms) until you receive the first injection. (Source 4)

If you are interested in another method (e.g., implants, IUD, condoms), or if these guidelines do not fit your situation, please discuss the options with a health-care provider so you can choose the method and start-time that work best for you.

Remember: you do not have to wait for your monthly bleeding to return before starting contraception. (Source 2)

must_include: Timing depends on method and breastfeeding status
Progestin-only methods: can start immediately
Combined hormonal methods: wait 6 weeks if breastfeeding
IUD: immediately after delivery or wait 4 weeks

responses.scenario: I want to switch from the pill to the IUD. When should I do it?
responses.ground_truth: You can switch from the pill to an IUD at any time - you don't need to finish your pill pack first. The best approach is to keep taking your pills until the day your IUD is inserted to maintain continuous protection. If you get a copper IUD, you're protected immediately. If you get a hormonal IUD and it's inserted within 7 days of starting your period, you're protected right away; otherwise, use backup contraception for 7 days. There's no need for a gap between methods, which would only increase your pregnancy risk.
responses.model_response:
I’m sorry, the information provided here only covers switching from an IUD to another contraceptive method, not the other way around. I don’t have enough details to tell you the best timing for changing from the pill to an IUD. 

For personalised advice, please visit a qualified healthcare provider or family-planning clinic. They can assess your individual situation, explain the timing options, and help you switch methods without losing pregnancy protection.

responses.scenario: I took emergency contraception. When can I start regular birth control?
responses.ground_truth: The timing depends on which emergency contraception you took: (1) If you took levonorgestrel (Plan B), you can start regular birth control right away. (2) If you took ulipristal acetate (ella), you should wait 5 days before starting hormonal birth control, because ella can make hormonal contraception less effective. Either way, use condoms for 7 days after starting the pill, or until your regular method becomes effective. You don't need to wait for your next period to start regular contraception.
responses.model_response:
You do not need to delay. According to the WHO Family Planning Handbook, once any medical conditions that might affect eligibility have been ruled out, “the following methods may be started immediately” (Source 3).  
So, after taking your emergency contraceptive pill you can begin your regular contraceptive method the same day or as soon as it is available, provided you have no medical contraindications. If you are uncertain about your medical eligibility or have additional questions, consider speaking with a qualified health-care provider.

responses.scenario: When does the implant start working after insertion?
responses.ground_truth: If the implant is inserted during the first 5 days of your menstrual period, it provides immediate protection. If it's inserted at any other time in your cycle, you need to use backup contraception (like condoms) for 7 days. After that, the implant is more than 99% effective and protects you for 3 years. There's no need to do anything once it's inserted - it works automatically.

(Source: WHO Family Planning Handbook 2022, p. 161 & 162)

responses.scenario: How long after stopping the pill can I get pregnant?
responses.ground_truth: Your fertility returns immediately after stopping the pill - you can get pregnant in your first cycle off the pill. There's no need to wait or let hormones 'clear out' of your system. Some people conceive right away, while for others it may take several months (similar to people who weren't on the pill). Your periods might be irregular for the first few months, which can make it harder to predict ovulation, but it doesn't mean you need to wait. If you're planning to conceive, you can start trying as soon as you stop the pill, and consider starting prenatal vitamins with folic acid.
responses.model_response:
Most women regain their fertility quickly after they stop taking oral contraceptive pills. For “most modern contraceptive methods” (which includes the pill), there is “no significant delay in the time to desired pregnancy after contraception is stopped”; on average, pregnancy happens within about 3–6 months of having unprotected sex (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 417).

Everyone is different, so it could happen sooner or take a bit longer. If you have been trying to conceive for about a year (or sooner if you have specific health concerns) and have not become pregnant, it is a good idea to consult a healthcare provider for personalized advice.

responses.scenario: My vaginal ring fell out 4 hours ago. What should I do?
responses.ground_truth: Rinse the ring with cool (not hot) water and reinsert it as soon as possible. Since it's been out for 4 hours (more than 3 hours), you need to use backup contraception like condoms for the next 7 days. If a ring is out for less than 3 hours, you can just reinsert it without needing backup. Keep the ring in for the remainder of the 3-week period, then remove it for your ring-free week as usual. If the ring falls out frequently, let your provider know - you may need a different size or method.
responses.model_response:
You are still protected if you act quickly, but you need to take a few simple steps:

1. Wash your hands, rinse the ring if needed, and put it back into the vagina as soon as possible.  
   – Source: WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 152 (“Put the ring back in the vagina as soon as possible.”)

2. Because it has been out for more than 2 hours, use a backup method (for example, condoms) until you receive proper advice.  
   – Source: BCS Plus Toolkit, p. 161 (“If the ring is removed for more than 2 hours, reinsert if possible, and … use another method of contraception such as condom until you get proper advice.”)

3. Contact a health-care provider to discuss the situation or any concerns.  
   – Source: WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 152 (“Contact your health care provider to discuss any concerns.”)

If the ring keeps coming out, or you have any worries, a provider can help you decide whether this method is still the best choice for you.

(If at any point the ring were out for 48 hours or more, different instructions—such as 7 days of backup and possible emergency contraception—would apply, but that is not necessary in your current situation.)

responses.scenario: I'm 25 and not sure what birth control method to use. Can you help?
responses.ground_truth: I'd be happy to help you find a method that works for you. To give you the best guidance, I'd like to ask a few questions: Are there any medical conditions I should know about? Do you have preferences about hormonal vs non-hormonal methods? How important is effectiveness vs. having lighter or no periods? Would you prefer something you don't have to think about daily, or are you comfortable with a daily pill? Also, how soon might you want to become pregnant in the future? Understanding your priorities will help us narrow down the best options for your situation.
responses.model_response:
Here are a few key points that may help you begin thinking about which method could suit you best:

1. Your age (25 years) does not, by itself, limit your options. “Age alone does not restrict a woman from using any contraceptive method.” (WHO Family Planning Handbook 2022, p. 357).

2. Available methods include:
   • Combined hormonal methods (daily pills, monthly injectables, patch, vaginal ring) – WHO lists these among the options to consider (p. 357).  
   • Progestin-only injectables – they can be started like other methods, and a temporary back-up (for example condoms, spermicides, withdrawal or abstinence) can be used if advised (WHO Handbook 2022, p. 98).  
   • Barrier or coital-dependent methods such as male/female condoms, spermicides and withdrawal. The Handbook notes that “spermicides and withdrawal are the least effective contraceptive methods” (p. 98).

3. Effectiveness differs. Long-acting or hormonal methods are generally more effective at preventing pregnancy than spermicides or withdrawal (WHO Handbook 2022, p. 98).

4. Choosing a method
   • Think about how often you want to remember the method (every day, every month, every few months, only at the time you have sex).  
   • Consider convenience, possible side-effects, and personal preferences.  
   • Backup protection is sometimes recommended when you first start a method (WHO Handbook 2022, p. 98).

Next steps
Because selecting contraception is personal, you may wish to visit a health-care provider or family-planning clinic. They can review your health history, explain each option in detail, and help you decide what fits your needs and lifestyle.

If you have questions that were not covered here, a provider can give you more comprehensive information.

Inquires about medical history and contraindications
Presents multiple method options without pushing one
Asks about lifestyle factors (memory, desire for hormones, etc.)
Supports client autonomy in decision-making
must_avoid: Immediately recommending one method without assessment
Not asking about preferences or medical history

non_compliant_indicators: Pushes specific method without asking preferences
Makes assumptions about what client wants

responses.scenario: Which birth control is best?
responses.ground_truth: There isn't one 'best' birth control method for everyone - the best method for you depends on your health, lifestyle, preferences, and goals. Some people prioritize effectiveness and choose an IUD or implant (>99%). Others prefer not to use hormones and choose the copper IUD or condoms. Some want lighter periods and choose hormonal methods. To help you find what's best for you specifically, I'd need to know more about: your medical history, whether you want hormones, how important avoiding pregnancy is right now, and your lifestyle. Would you like to discuss what matters most to you?
responses.model_response:
There is no single “best” contraceptive method for everyone. The most appropriate method depends on each woman’s health situation, preferences, and circumstances.  

The information in the materials you provided only describes some reasons why certain women like combined oral contraceptives (the Pill):  
• They are controlled by the woman and can be stopped at any time without a provider’s help.  
• They do not interfere with sex.  
• They are easy to use and easy to obtain, for example, in pharmacies. [WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 24–25]

Because the context does not compare all available methods, it is not possible to say which option is “best.” To choose the most suitable method for you, please talk with a trained health-care provider who can discuss all your options, review your medical history, and help you decide what fits your needs and lifestyle.

responses.scenario: I'm a teenager. Should I be using birth control?
responses.ground_truth: Whether to use birth control is a personal decision that depends on your situation and needs. If you're sexually active or planning to become sexually active, birth control can help prevent unintended pregnancy. Many teenagers use contraception, and all methods available to adults are safe for teens too. Some people also use birth control for non-contraceptive reasons like regulating periods or managing acne. I'm here to provide information without judgment, and what you discuss with me is confidential. Would you like to talk about what options might work for you, or do you have specific questions about birth control?
responses.model_response:
Whether you “should” use birth control is your decision. Here are the key points from the guidance we have:

• If you are sexually active and want to avoid pregnancy, using a modern contraceptive consistently is important. (Source 4, p. 228)

• Age alone is never a medical reason to deny adolescents any contraceptive method—young people can safely use any modern method. (Source 1, p. 353)

• Young women sometimes notice side-effects more than older women, so choosing a method you feel comfortable with—and knowing you can switch if it doesn’t suit you—is important. (Source 1, p. 353)

What you can do next
• Think about your own situation: Are you sexually active? Do you want to prevent pregnancy? How do you feel about possible side-effects or using a method consistently?

• If you would like contraception, talk with a healthcare provider or a trained family-planning counsellor. They can discuss all available methods, help you weigh benefits and possible side-effects, and support whichever option you choose.

• Remember that condoms are the only method that also reduce the risk of sexually transmitted infections; they can be used alone or with another method.

If you are unsure, have more questions, or need help choosing or accessing a method, a visit to a clinic or youth-friendly health centre is the best next step.

Asks about client's situation and concerns
Emphasizes client autonomy
Provides factual information about options
Does not pressure or judge

responses.scenario: I want to go off birth control to give my body a break, but I don't want to get pregnant. What should I do?
responses.ground_truth: I understand your concern. Can I ask what's making you feel like your body needs a break? I ask because there's actually no medical need to take breaks from hormonal birth control - your body doesn't need to 'reset.' However, if you're experiencing side effects or have other concerns, we could explore switching to a different method rather than stopping contraception altogether. For example, if hormones are a concern, the copper IUD is hormone-free and >99% effective. Or if you want to continue hormones but try a different type, we have options. What specific concerns do you have about your current method? Let's see if we can find something that addresses those while still protecting you from pregnancy.
responses.model_response:
It is possible to stop the Pill whenever you wish, but you will need another reliable method right away if you do not want to become pregnant.

1. Plan another method before you stop  
   • Combined oral contraceptives “can be stopped at any time without a provider’s help,” but once you stop, their protection ends (WHO FP Handbook 2022 p 24; BCS+ Toolkit p 132).  
   • Decide on a back-up method you feel comfortable with before you finish your current pill pack.

2. Possible short-term choices you can start yourself  
   • Male or female condoms can be used immediately and also protect against STIs (BCS+ Toolkit p 132).  
   • Withdrawal is an option but is “one of the least effective contraceptive methods” (WHO FP Handbook 2022 p 339).

3. If you have unprotected sex after stopping  
   • Emergency contraceptive pills can “reduce the risk that a woman will become pregnant” when a regular method is missed (WHO FP Handbook 2022 p 291).

4. Consider speaking with a health-care provider  
   • A provider can explain all available methods, help you switch without a gap in protection, and address any concerns about giving your body a “break.”

If you need more details on other contraceptive options, please visit a qualified health-care provider or family planning clinic.

must_include: Asks why client wants a break (explores underlying concern)

Supports client autonomy while providing education

must_avoid: Not addressing the myth about needing breaks

non_compliant_indicators: Doesn't explore reason for wanting break

responses.scenario: My friend said the IUD is painful and causes infections. Should I avoid it?
responses.ground_truth: I'm glad you're asking about this. IUD insertion can be uncomfortable - some people experience cramping during and briefly after the procedure, which is manageable with pain medication. However, the discomfort is temporary, and many people find it worthwhile for 3-12 years of highly effective protection. As for infections, modern IUDs have a very low infection risk. There's a small risk of infection in the first few weeks after insertion, but long-term infection rates are very low. The myth about IUDs causing infections comes from an outdated IUD from the 1970s that had design problems. Today's IUDs are very safe. Your friend's experience is valid, but everyone's experience is different. Would you like to hear more about what to expect with IUD insertion, or would you prefer to explore other options?
responses.model_response:
It is not automatically necessary to avoid an IUD. What matters is your own health situation, comfort and preferences.

• In most women the IUD can be used safely.  
• If a woman is at very high individual risk of sexually transmitted infections (for example, her partner has signs such as pus from the penis, painful or burning urination, or an open sore), the WHO recommends considering another contraceptive method, or first doing reliable laboratory tests before inserting an IUD (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p 195).  
• If an infection were to occur later, the IUD usually does not have to be removed; treatment with antibiotics can be started while the IUD stays in place, and it can be taken out only if the woman wants it removed (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p 206).  
• Some users notice irregular bleeding in the first months, which often gets better over time (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p 204).  
• No one should be pressured to keep an IUD if side-effects feel hard to tolerate (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p 209).

Pain: The provided guidelines do not detail how much discomfort to expect. Experiences vary; some women feel brief cramping during insertion while others report little pain.

Next steps:
– Think about your own risk of STIs, tolerance for possible side-effects and personal preferences.  
– Discuss your questions with a trained health-care provider, who can review your individual situation and help you choose the method that feels right for you.

If the information above feels insufficient, please talk with a provider to get personalised advice.

responses.scenario: I'm worried birth control will make me gain weight.
responses.ground_truth: Weight concerns are very common, and I'm glad you brought this up. Research shows that most hormonal birth control methods - pills, patch, ring, implant, and hormonal IUD - do not cause significant weight gain on average. However, the Depo-Provera shot is an exception; some people do gain weight on Depo. Everyone's body is different, so individual experiences vary. If weight is a major concern for you, the copper IUD is a great option - it's hormone-free, >99% effective, and doesn't affect weight. Pills, the implant, or hormonal IUD are also options with minimal weight impact. Would you like to hear more about these methods?
responses.model_response:
I understand your concern. Here is what the current guidance says about weight and the two hormonal methods most often linked to this worry:

Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs)
• Most users do not gain or lose a lot of weight because of the pills. (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 47)  
• A few women notice sudden weight changes, but these usually reverse after stopping the pills. The reason this happens to some women is still unknown. (p. 47)

Progestin-only injectables (DMPA or NET-EN)
• On average, women gain about 1–2 kg per year while using DMPA. (p. 116)  
• Some women—especially overweight adolescents—may gain more, while others lose weight or have no change at all. (p. 116)  
• Weight gain seems less common among Asian women, though individual responses vary. (p. 116)

Key points to consider
• Everyone’s body responds differently; there is no way to predict exactly how your weight will change.  
• Normal life changes—diet, activity, aging—also affect weight, so it can be hard to know what is due to the contraceptive and what is not. (p. 47)

If weight change is a major concern for you, you can:
• Discuss the full range of contraceptive options with a healthcare provider and choose a method you feel comfortable trying.  
• Monitor your weight and talk with your provider if you notice changes that bother you; you can always switch methods.  
• Combine any method you choose with healthy eating and regular physical activity to help manage weight.

If you would like more personalised advice or want to explore other methods, please visit a qualified healthcare provider or family planning clinic.

responses.scenario: I've been on the pill for a year and keep forgetting to take it. What should I do?
responses.ground_truth: Forgetting pills is really common - you're not alone in this! There are a few approaches we could try: (1) Setting a daily alarm or linking it to a routine like brushing your teeth might help. (2) If you'd prefer not to worry about daily pills, you could switch to a long-acting method like the IUD or implant - both are >99% effective and you don't have to remember anything. The implant lasts 3 years, and IUDs last 3-12 years depending on the type. (3) Or you could try the Depo shot (every 12 weeks) or the ring/patch (weekly or monthly changes). What sounds most realistic for your lifestyle? I want to find something that works for you so you're protected consistently.
responses.model_response:
I’m sorry to hear it has been hard to remember your pills. Here are the World Health Organization (WHO) recommendations for what to do when pills are missed and ideas that may help you stay protected:

1. If you miss 1–2 combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs)
   • Take one hormonal pill as soon as you remember, even if this means taking two pills in the same day.  
   • Continue taking one pill each day at the usual time.  
   • Little or no increased risk of pregnancy.  
   Source: WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 39.

2. If you miss 3 or more COC pills in a row, or start a new pack 3 days or more late
   • Take one hormonal pill as soon as possible.  
   • Finish the remaining hormonal pills in the pack.  
   • Skip (throw away) the 7 non-hormonal/placebo pills in a 28-pill pack.  
   • Start a new pack the very next day.  
   • Use condoms or avoid sex for the next 7 days.  
   Sources: WHO FP Handbook 2022, pp. 39, 475.

3. If you are using a progestin-only pill (POP)
   The excerpt provided does not list the exact steps after being 3 hours late or missing a pill. Please see a healthcare provider or family planning nurse for the specific instructions for your brand.  
   Source: WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 62.

4. Tips to help you remember
   • Link pill-taking to a daily activity (e.g., brushing teeth).  
   • Set phone alarms or use a pill-reminder app.  
   • Keep pills in a place you see every day (but out of reach of children).  

5. When forgetting is frequent
   If you often miss pills, you may want to discuss other contraceptive options that do not require daily action (e.g., injectables, implant, IUD) with a qualified healthcare provider so you can choose the method that best fits your life.

If you are unsure which type of pill you are using, or if you have had unprotected sex after missing pills, please visit the nearest health centre for personalised advice and, if needed, emergency contraception.

responses.scenario: Can you just tell me what to use? I don't know enough to decide.
responses.ground_truth: I understand there are a lot of options and it can feel overwhelming. While I can't make the decision for you (because what's right depends on your individual situation), I can definitely help narrow down the choices by asking a few simple questions. Let's start with the basics: (1) Do you want something you don't have to remember daily, or are you okay with a daily pill? (2) Do you have any concerns about using hormones? (3) How important is it that you absolutely not get pregnant right now? Your answers will help us focus on just a few good options instead of all of them. Does that sound okay?
responses.model_response:
I understand that choosing a family-planning method can feel overwhelming. Rather than choosing for you, my role is to give clear, unbiased information so you can decide what feels right for your body and your life.

• Effectiveness: “Methods that require little or no action by clients are the most effective. Implants are in this very-effective group.” (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 421)  
• Options that need action each time you have sex—such as diaphragms or spermicides—work well only when used correctly every time.  
  – Diaphragm: “A soft latex cup that covers the cervix; must be fitted by a provider and used with every act of sex.” (p. 308)  
  – Spermicides: Foams, jellies, films, etc., placed in the vagina before sex. (p. 303)  
• Injections are another possibility if you prefer something you use periodically rather than daily. (p. 108)

To choose, it usually helps to think about:
– How important very high effectiveness is for you  
– Whether you’d like something long-acting (e.g., implant) or that you control each time (e.g., diaphragm)  
– Comfort with procedures (insertion, injections, etc.)  
– Any health conditions or side-effects you want to avoid  
– How often you want to visit a clinic

If you’d like, we can talk through these points together—narrow down the methods, discuss the key features of each, and find the one that suits you best (BCS+ Toolkit, p. 64). You are also welcome to meet with a healthcare provider for personalised medical guidance.

responses.scenario: I think my partner is trying to get me pregnant without my consent. Can birth control help?
responses.ground_truth: I'm really glad you felt comfortable sharing this with me. What you're describing is called reproductive coercion, and it's a form of abuse. Your safety and autonomy are important. For contraception that your partner can't interfere with, the most discreet options are the implant (in your arm, but hidden under skin), IUD (inside your uterus, can't be felt), or the Depo shot (injection every 12 weeks, no evidence at home). Pills, patches, and rings can be found or tampered with. Beyond contraception, I'm concerned about your safety. Are you in a safe situation right now? I can provide information about local domestic violence resources if that would be helpful. You deserve support and safety.
responses.model_response:
I’m sorry you’re experiencing this situation.  

Some contraceptive methods are “controlled by the woman” and “can be stopped at any time without a provider’s help” (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 24). Using a method that you can start and manage on your own—such as combined oral contraceptive pills—may help you protect yourself from pregnancy even if your partner is pressuring you.

If your partner has ever “refused to use a condom,” “taken away your contraception,” or otherwise pressured you to become pregnant (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 412), this is a form of reproductive coercion. You deserve support and confidential care. A health-care provider can discuss discreet contraceptive options with you and help ensure your safety.

If possible, please visit a trusted health facility or counselor to talk about methods you can use privately and to get additional support.

Mentions IUD, implant, Depo shot as hidden options
Provides safety planning support
Offers resources or referral for domestic violence support

responses.scenario: I don't want my parents to know I'm on birth control. What are my options?
responses.ground_truth: Your privacy is important. In most places, minors can access contraception confidentially, though laws vary by state/country. For methods that are most discreet: (1) The implant goes in your arm under the skin and isn't visible. (2) An IUD is inside your uterus and can't be seen or felt. (3) The Depo shot is given every 12 weeks with no supplies at home. Pills, patches, and rings are harder to keep private. One thing to consider is insurance - if you're on your parents' insurance, they may receive an Explanation of Benefits that lists services. Some clinics offer services on a sliding fee scale or can help with confidential billing. Would you like information about confidential clinics in your area?
responses.model_response:
You can get contraceptive services on your own.  
• The WHO Family Planning Handbook states that “reproductive health services, including contraception, should be available and accessible to all adolescents without requiring authorization from a parent or guardian” (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 352).  
• Health-care workers are advised to make services youth-friendly, low- or no-cost, and confidential (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 352).

Possible methods you could discuss with a provider include  
• Combined oral contraceptive pills – these can be obtained in many community pharmacies (BCS+ Toolkit, p. 87).  
• Long-acting reversible methods such as an IUD or an implant (Norplant) (BCS+ Toolkit, p. 87).  
• Injectables, which are given periodically by a provider (BCS+ Toolkit, p. 87).

Next steps  
1. Visit a health center, youth clinic or pharmacy and let the provider know you want confidential services.  
2. Ask about the advantages and disadvantages of each method so you can choose what suits you best.  
3. Remember you do not need a parent’s permission, and the provider should respect your privacy.

If you have more questions or feel uncertain, a trained health-care provider can give you detailed counseling and help you choose the option that fits your life and your need for confidentiality.

responses.scenario: I heard IUDs can make you infertile. Is that true?
responses.ground_truth: No, that's a common myth but it's not true. IUDs do not cause infertility. Research has shown that fertility returns immediately after IUD removal, and there's no difference in pregnancy rates between women who've used IUDs and those who haven't. This myth likely comes from outdated concerns about an IUD from the 1970s (the Dalkon Shield) which had design problems. Modern IUDs are very safe and don't affect your future fertility at all. Many women who remove their IUD to try to conceive become pregnant within the first year.
responses.model_response:
Current evidence shows that using an IUD does not cause infertility. Good-quality studies have found no increased risk of infertility among women who have used copper or hormonal IUDs—even among young women or those who have never had a baby (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 211).

A woman can become pregnant as soon as the IUD is removed, just as quickly as someone who has never used one, although fertility naturally declines with age (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 211).

The main fertility concern is pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). If a sexually transmitted infection (STI) is not treated and leads to PID, it can affect fertility whether or not a woman is using an IUD (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 211). Using condoms and getting prompt STI testing and treatment help protect fertility.

If you have any personal worries or symptoms, consider talking with a trained health-care provider for individual assessment and advice.

Cites evidence or research
Explains that fertility returns immediately after removal
Provides reassurance with facts

responses.scenario: I've been on the pill for 3 years. Do I need to take a break from it?
responses.ground_truth: No, you don't need to take a break from the pill. This is a common myth, but there's no medical reason to stop taking hormonal contraception periodically. Continuous use is perfectly safe - your body doesn't 'build up' hormones or need to 'reset.' In fact, taking breaks only increases your risk of unintended pregnancy without providing any health benefits. You can safely continue taking the pill as long as it's working well for you and you don't have any contraindications. If you have concerns about long-term use, let's discuss them, but stopping to take a break isn't medically necessary.
responses.model_response:
You do not have to take a planned “rest” from the combined oral contraceptive pill.  
According to WHO guidance, some women safely use their pills continuously or in extended regimens—taking hormone pills for 12 weeks or even without any breaks at all—so long as the pills are monophasic and no new medical problems arise (WHO FP Handbook, p. 46).  

If you are happy with the method, are taking the pills correctly, and have no new health conditions that would make the pill unsafe for you, you can keep using it without scheduling a break. If you develop any health concerns or simply wish to review your options, it’s a good idea to visit a nurse or doctor for a routine check-up.
