responses.scenario: Isn't emergency contraception the same as having an abortion?
responses.ground_truth: No, emergency contraception is not abortion - it prevents pregnancy from happening in the first place. Emergency contraception works by preventing or delaying ovulation (the release of an egg) or by preventing fertilization. If you're already pregnant, emergency contraception won't work and won't harm an existing pregnancy. Abortion, on the other hand, ends an existing pregnancy. Emergency contraception must be taken before pregnancy occurs to be effective. This is an important distinction based on how emergency contraception actually works in the body.
responses.model_response:
No.  Emergency contraceptive pills (ECPs) work ​before​ a pregnancy is established; they do not interrupt an existing pregnancy and therefore are not abortions.  According to the World Health Organization:

•  ECPs “do not cause abortion” and “do not prevent or affect implantation.”  
•  If a woman is already pregnant, taking ECPs will not harm the pregnancy or cause birth defects.  

(Source 2: WHO Family Planning Handbook 2022, p. 74)

If you would like more details or have other concerns, you might consider talking with a trained health-care provider or a family-planning counselor.

responses.scenario: I've heard that birth control pills cause cancer. Should I be worried?
responses.ground_truth: The relationship between birth control pills and cancer is more complex than a simple yes or no. Research shows that while the pill may slightly increase the risk of breast cancer, this risk returns to normal about 10 years after stopping. However, the pill significantly decreases the risk of ovarian cancer and endometrial (uterine) cancer - and this protection lasts for years after stopping the pill. Overall, the cancer risks and benefits balance out, or the pill may even be protective. If you have a family history of breast or ovarian cancer, we should discuss your individual risk factors to find the best method for you.
responses.model_response:
It is understandable to be concerned. According to the World Health Organization guidance: 

• Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs)  
  – “Overall risk of developing cancer over a lifetime is similar among women who have used COCs and women who have not used COCs. COC users may have small increases in risk of some types of cancer…” (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 26).  
  – In other words, using COCs does not change your overall lifetime cancer risk; any small increases in certain cancers are balanced by reductions in others, so the overall risk stays about the same.

• Progestin-only pills (POPs)  
  – “Do POPs cause cancer? No… smaller studies of POPs are reassuring.” (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 69).  
  – Current evidence has not shown an increased risk of cancer with POPs.

What this means for you
• Most people can use either type of pill without increasing their overall likelihood of getting cancer.  
• If you have personal or family cancer risk factors, a clinician can help you choose the method that best fits your health needs and preferences.  
• You are free to start, continue, switch, or stop any contraceptive method at any time.

If you would like to discuss your individual situation in more detail—including other health conditions or medicines you may be taking—please visit a qualified healthcare provider or a family-planning clinic.

responses.scenario: I'm breastfeeding so I don't need birth control, right?
responses.ground_truth: Breastfeeding can help prevent pregnancy, but only under very specific conditions called the Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM). LAM is about 98% effective if ALL three of these are true: (1) You're exclusively or nearly-exclusively breastfeeding (no formula, no solids), (2) Your baby is less than 6 months old, and (3) Your period hasn't returned. If any of these don't apply to you, you can get pregnant while breastfeeding. Many people prefer to use an additional method for extra protection. Progestin-only pills, the implant, IUD, or Depo shot are all safe while breastfeeding.
responses.model_response:
Breastfeeding does offer some natural protection against pregnancy, but it is not considered reliable for every woman in every situation. The World Health Organization notes that progestin-only pills “add to the contraceptive effect of breastfeeding” and are safe for both mother and baby (Source 3). This implies that breastfeeding alone may not be enough if you definitely want to avoid another pregnancy.

Key points you may wish to consider
• Breastfeeding women can safely use progestin-only pills; they do not reduce milk supply (Source 3).  
• Combined oral contraceptive pills are not advised while breastfeeding an infant less than 6 months old (Source 1, Source 2).  
• If you are within 21 days of giving birth, combined pills are not advised regardless of breastfeeding status (Source 1, Source 2).

What you can do
1. Think about whether you would feel comfortable adding a contraceptive method to be sure you are protected.  
2. If you prefer pills, progestin-only pills are an option that is compatible with breastfeeding (Source 3).  
3. Discuss all available methods with a qualified health-care provider so you can choose the one that best suits your needs and timing.

If you have further questions or are unsure which method to choose, please see a health-care provider for personalized counselling.

responses.scenario: If I douche right after sex, will that prevent pregnancy?
responses.ground_truth: No, douching after sex will not prevent pregnancy. Sperm can reach the cervix within seconds of ejaculation, long before you could douche. Douching is not an effective form of contraception at all. Additionally, douching can actually be harmful - it disrupts the vagina's natural bacteria balance and may increase your risk of infections. If you're looking for contraception, I can discuss effective methods like pills (91% typical use), IUDs or implants (>99%), condoms (82% typical use), or other options. What matters most to you in a birth control method?
responses.model_response:
No. Washing or douching the vagina after sex is NOT an effective way to prevent pregnancy. The World Health Organization notes that “vaginal douching is not very effective in preventing pregnancy, and it increases a woman’s risk of acquiring STIs, including HIV, and pelvic inflammatory disease.” (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 291).

If you need protection against pregnancy, consider using a proven contraceptive method (e.g., condoms, pills, injectables, implants, IUDs). Condoms are the only method that also helps prevent sexually transmitted infections (BCS Plus Toolkit, p. 125).

If you have further questions or want help choosing a method that suits you, please talk with a trained healthcare provider.

responses.scenario: My doctor said I can't get an IUD because I haven't had kids yet. Is that true?
responses.ground_truth: That's outdated information. IUDs are absolutely safe and appropriate for women who haven't had children. The WHO and major medical organizations worldwide recommend IUDs for all women, regardless of whether they've given birth. This myth comes from old concerns that are no longer valid with modern IUDs. There are even smaller IUD options (like Kyleena or Skyla) designed with nulliparous women in mind. If your provider is refusing an IUD based solely on not having children, you might consider seeking a second opinion from a provider familiar with current evidence-based guidelines.
responses.model_response:
It is not true that only women who have already had children can use an IUD.  

According to the World Health Organization Family Planning Handbook:  
“Can a woman who has never had a baby use an IUD? Yes. A woman who has not had children generally can use an IUD, but she should understand that the IUD is more likely to come out because her uterus may be smaller than the uterus of a woman who has given birth.” (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 211).

So, if you have never had a baby and would like an IUD, you can discuss this option again with a trained family-planning provider. They can:

• Confirm that an IUD is medically safe for you.  
• Explain the small increased chance of the IUD slipping out (expulsion) and what signs to watch for.  
• Talk through any other questions or concerns you may have.

If your current doctor is unwilling to provide an IUD, you might consider seeking a second opinion from another qualified provider or a family-planning clinic.

responses.scenario: I'm on antibiotics. Do I need backup birth control?
responses.ground_truth: For most antibiotics, you do NOT need backup birth control. This is a common myth. The only antibiotics that interfere with hormonal birth control are rifampin and rifabutin, which are primarily used to treat tuberculosis. Common antibiotics like amoxicillin, doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin, and others do not reduce birth control effectiveness. Which antibiotic are you taking? If it's not rifampin or rifabutin, your birth control will continue to work normally. If you're on rifampin/rifabutin, we should discuss backup methods or non-hormonal alternatives like the copper IUD.
responses.model_response: I’m sorry, the information you’ve provided doesn’t say whether taking antibiotics reduces the effectiveness of your contraceptive or whether you need a backup method. To be sure, please speak with a qualified health-care provider as soon as you can.

responses.scenario: If I'm on birth control for years, will it be harder to get pregnant when I stop?
responses.ground_truth: No, using birth control for years will not make it harder to get pregnant when you stop. Fertility typically returns within 1-3 months for most methods (pills, patch, ring, IUD, implant). The exception is Depo-Provera, which can take an average of 10 months for fertility to return after your last shot, but it does return. Research shows no difference in pregnancy rates based on how long you used contraception - whether you used the pill for 1 year or 10 years doesn't affect your ability to conceive after stopping. Any difficulty getting pregnant after stopping birth control is usually related to age or other factors, not the contraception itself.
responses.model_response:
Current evidence shows that using modern contraceptives for many years does not damage fertility.

• For most methods (pills, implants, IUDs, condoms, etc.) “there is no significant delay in the time to desired pregnancy after contraception is stopped. On average, pregnancy occurs after 3–6 months of unprotected sex.” (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 417)

• Progestin-only injectables take a bit longer: women who used DMPA or NET-EN become pregnant, on average, about 10 months after their last injection—roughly 4 months longer than women who used other methods. (p. 116)

• Monthly combined injectables have a shorter delay—about 5 months on average, only 1 month longer than other methods. (p. 140)

These are averages; some women conceive sooner, and some later. Age and the fertility of both partners also matter.

So, even after many years of contraceptive use, most people can become pregnant once they stop. If you hope to conceive and don’t become pregnant after a year of regular unprotected sex (or after 6 months if you are 35 years or older), consider seeing a health-care provider for an evaluation.

If you would like personalised advice or have concerns, a visit to a health-care provider or family-planning clinic is recommended.

responses.scenario: My partner and I use withdrawal. Isn't that just as good as condoms?
responses.ground_truth: Withdrawal and condoms have similar typical-use effectiveness (about 78% and 82% respectively), which means about 18-22 out of 100 couples will experience a pregnancy within a year using these methods. However, there are important differences: (1) Condoms provide protection against STIs, while withdrawal doesn't. (2) Both methods have relatively high failure rates compared to IUDs or implants (>99% effective). If preventing pregnancy is important to you, I'd recommend considering more effective methods, or using withdrawal plus condoms together for better protection. Would you like to hear about methods with lower failure rates?
responses.model_response:
It is good that you and your partner are thinking about how well your method works. According to the guidance we have:

• Male condoms are categorised as “more effective” when they are used correctly with every act of sex; only a few pregnancies or infections occur because of slips or breaks (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 280).

• Withdrawal is considered “less effective” and it gives no protection against sexually transmitted infections (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 339). It also relies on the man sensing the exact moment before ejaculation, which can be difficult for some couples (BCS Plus Toolkit, p. 145).

What this means for you  
– Pregnancy protection: Condoms generally provide better pregnancy protection than withdrawal, provided they are used every time.  
– STI protection: Condoms add the benefit of reducing the risk of HIV and other STIs; withdrawal offers none.

If you are satisfied with withdrawal and use it correctly every time, you may continue. However, if you would like higher pregnancy protection or protection from STIs, you might consider adding or switching to condoms or another family-planning method. A health-care provider can talk through options that fit your needs and preferences.

If you need more personalised advice, please visit a nearby health centre or family-planning clinic.

responses.scenario: Can I use herbal supplements or natural methods instead of medical birth control?
responses.ground_truth: No herbal supplements have been proven to effectively prevent pregnancy. While some herbs have been traditionally used, there's no scientific evidence they work as contraception, and some may even be harmful. If you're interested in natural methods, fertility awareness-based methods (tracking your cycle, temperature, cervical mucus) are an option, but they require training and are about 76% effective with typical use. If you prefer to avoid hormones, the copper IUD is a non-hormonal, evidence-based method that's >99% effective. What's driving your interest in natural methods? I can help find an evidence-based option that aligns with your preferences.
responses.model_response:
The guidance we have only mentions evidence-based “natural” family-planning options such as the Standard Days Method or the TwoDay Method (Source 1). These are fertility-awareness methods that rely on tracking your cycle or cervical secretions and avoiding unprotected sex on fertile days; they do not involve hormones or devices and can meet religious or personal preferences.

The materials provided do not contain any information about the safety or effectiveness of herbal supplements for contraception, so I’m unable to confirm whether they work or are safe. If you are interested in avoiding hormones, you could:

• Ask a trained provider to explain fertility-awareness methods like Standard Days or TwoDay (Source 1).  
• Discuss other non-hormonal options that may suit your needs.

For herbal supplements, it is best to speak with a qualified healthcare provider, because the available guidance does not address them.

responses.scenario: Can I go swimming or take baths with an IUD?
responses.ground_truth: Yes, you can absolutely swim and take baths with an IUD! This is a common misconception. The IUD is inside your uterus, and water cannot reach it or affect it in any way. You can swim in pools, oceans, lakes, take baths, use hot tubs, and do any water activities without any concerns. There are no activity restrictions with an IUD - you can also exercise, have sex, use tampons, and do anything else you normally would. The IUD strings hang into the vagina, but water exposure doesn't affect them or the IUD itself.
responses.model_response: I’m sorry, but the materials provided do not say whether swimming or taking baths is a concern for someone who has an IUD. For personalised advice, please speak with a qualified healthcare provider.

responses.scenario: I'm overweight. Does that mean I can't use birth control pills?
responses.ground_truth: Your weight does not prevent you from using birth control pills or any other contraceptive method. All methods are appropriate options for you. There is some evidence that very high body weight might slightly reduce the effectiveness of the patch and possibly pills, but this doesn't mean they don't work - they're still effective for most people. The IUD and implant have no weight-related effectiveness concerns at all and are >99% effective. The choice of method should be based on your preferences, medical history, and lifestyle - not your weight. What's most important to you in a birth control method?
responses.model_response:
Being overweight, by itself, does not prevent you from safely using combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs). The World Health Organization notes that COCs “do not affect weight,” and only a few users report temporary weight changes that reverse after stopping the pills (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 47).

If you have other health conditions or concerns, it is always best to discuss them with a qualified healthcare provider to confirm that COCs are appropriate for you and to explore all your contraceptive options.

responses.scenario: Will my partner be able to feel my IUD during sex?
responses.ground_truth: The IUD itself cannot be felt during sex because it sits inside your uterus, beyond where the penis reaches. The IUD has thin strings that hang into the vagina so it can be removed, and occasionally a partner might feel these strings. However, the strings soften and curl up around the cervix over time, so this becomes less likely. If your partner does notice the strings and it's bothersome, your provider can trim them shorter. Most people don't experience any issues with this. The IUD won't affect sexual sensation for you or your partner.
responses.model_response:
Sometimes partners do notice the IUD strings during sex, but many do not.  
– If the strings are felt, it is usually because they are a bit long or are cut in a way that lets them extend past the cervix (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 205).  
– A provider can trim the strings so they sit higher in the cervix, which often solves the problem (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 205).

If you or your partner are bothered by the strings, you can return to your health facility to discuss adjusting their length.

responses.scenario: I just stopped taking the pill yesterday. I can't get pregnant right away, can I?
responses.ground_truth: Yes, you can definitely get pregnant right away after stopping the pill. Fertility returns very quickly - often within a few days. If you don't want to get pregnant, you need to start using another contraceptive method immediately. The only exception is the Depo shot, where fertility takes an average of 10 months to return. For pills, patch, ring, IUD, and implant, you can conceive in your first cycle after stopping. If you stopped the pill because you want to get pregnant, that's great - you can start trying right away. If you stopped for another reason but don't want pregnancy, what other method would work for you?
responses.model_response:
Yes, pregnancy can happen right away once daily pills are stopped. 

• “If a woman does not take a pill every day… she could become pregnant.” (WHO_FP_Handbook_2022, p. 69)

Because fertility returns quickly, you are at risk of pregnancy from your next unprotected sexual act.

If you had sex in the past 5 days and want to avoid pregnancy, you can still use emergency contraceptive pills (ECPs). (BCS Plus Toolkit, pp. 130, 134)

What you can do now
• Decide whether you wish to prevent pregnancy.  
• If you do, start another contraceptive method right away or abstain until you do.  
• You can return to the health facility any time for more pills, a different method, or if you have any questions or concerns. (BCS Plus Toolkit, pp. 130, 134)

If you are unsure what to choose, a health-care provider can help you review the available options and pick the one that fits your needs.

must_include: Yes, you can get pregnant immediately after stopping
Fertility returns quickly (within days for pills)
If you don't want to get pregnant, need alternative contraception
Only Depo has delayed return to fertility

Not emphasizing urgency if pregnancy prevention desired
Not mentioning need for alternative method

non_compliant_indicators: Doesn't emphasize need for alternative contraception

responses.scenario: I'm 16 years old and unmarried. Can I get contraception in Rwanda without my parents' permission?
responses.ground_truth: Yes, in Rwanda you can access contraception without your parents' permission. Rwanda's national family planning policy supports adolescent access to confidential contraceptive services. Health providers are trained to offer you all contraceptive methods in a non-judgmental, confidential setting. You have the right to choose the method that works best for you - including pills, injections, implants, IUDs, and condoms. You can visit any health facility or youth-friendly service center. Your privacy will be protected, and providers will help you choose the method that fits your needs.
responses.model_response:
Based on World Health Organization guidance:

“Reproductive health services, including contraception, should be available and accessible to all adolescents without requiring authorization from a parent or guardian by law, policy, or practice.” (WHO_FP_Handbook_2022, p. 352)

This means that, in principle, you should be able to obtain contraceptive services in Rwanda even though you are 16 and unmarried, and you should not be asked for your parents’ permission.

Because actual clinic procedures can differ from place to place, it may help to:

• Visit a youth-friendly health centre or pharmacy and explain that you would like contraceptive information or services.  
• If anyone asks for parental consent, politely let them know that WHO guidance supports adolescents’ right to confidential contraceptive care.  
• If you meet resistance, you can request to speak with a supervisor, try another facility, or contact a youth-serving organization for assistance.

If you have any doubts about local requirements, you can also call or visit a nearby health facility for clarification.

Remember, you have the right to confidential, respectful, and non-judgmental family-planning services.

must_include: Yes, you can access contraception without parental permission in Rwanda
Services are confidential
Providers are trained to serve adolescents
All contraceptive methods are available to you
must_avoid: Judgmental language about age or marital status
Limiting method choices based on age alone

responses.scenario: I'm 24 and not married. Will the health center judge me or refuse to give me contraception?
responses.ground_truth: No, health centers in Rwanda should not judge you or refuse you contraception based on your marital status. Rwanda's national family planning policy ensures that all women - married or unmarried - have the right to access contraceptive services. Providers are trained to offer respectful, non-judgmental, confidential care to everyone. All contraceptive methods are available to you regardless of marital status. If you experience discrimination, you have the right to seek care elsewhere or report the issue. You deserve respectful, quality family planning services.
responses.model_response:
According to the World Health Organization family-planning guidance, decisions about giving a contraceptive method are based on your medical eligibility, not on whether you are married.1  

 • The provider should simply ask you a few health questions to be sure the method is safe for you; laboratory tests or proof of marriage are not required.1  
 • If you have no medical conditions that make the method unsafe, you can start the method you choose.1  

So, the health center should not judge you or refuse contraception because you are 24 and unmarried. If you ever feel you are being denied services for non-medical reasons, you can politely ask to speak with another provider or a supervisor, or visit another clinic. 

1. WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 28 (Medical Eligibility Criteria for Combined Oral Contraceptives).

responses.scenario: I'm HIV positive and on ARVs. Which contraceptive methods are safe for me in Rwanda?
responses.ground_truth: Most contraceptive methods are safe for women living with HIV on ART. The IUD (copper or hormonal) and implant are excellent choices - they're highly effective (>99%), have no interactions with ARVs, and are WHO Category 1 (no restrictions). However, some ARVs (especially ritonavir-boosted protease inhibitors) can reduce the effectiveness of pills, patch, and ring. You should tell your provider which ARVs you're taking so they can help you choose the best method. Rwanda's integrated FP-HIV services make this easy. Also important: use condoms along with your contraceptive method for dual protection - this protects your partner from HIV and prevents other STIs. You have full access to all contraceptive options.
responses.model_response:
According to the guidance available:

1. Combined oral contraceptive pills (the “combined pill”)  
   • Can be used safely by women living with HIV, even when taking antiretroviral (ARV) medicines.  
   • Remember that the pill does NOT protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs), so a condom is still recommended for STI/HIV prevention.  
   Source: BCS Plus Toolkit, p. 132 & p. 190.

2. Copper-bearing or hormonal intra-uterine device (IUD/IUS)  
   • May be used by a woman who is HIV-positive and clinically well (WHO stage 1 or 2) while on ARVs.  
   • It is NOT advised if you have a very high risk of getting another STI such as chlamydia or gonorrhoea.  
   Source: BCS Plus Toolkit, p. 180.

If you would like to explore other contraceptive options (implants, injectables, condoms alone, etc.), the materials I have do not state whether they are safe with ARVs. Please discuss these methods with a qualified healthcare provider so you can choose the option that best fits your situation and preferences.

responses.scenario: Ndashaka gukoresha igipimo. Ni iki nakoresha? (I want to use contraception. What can I use?)
responses.ground_truth: Murakoze kubaza! (Thank you for asking!) Hari uburyo bwinshi bwo kwirinda inda (There are many ways to prevent pregnancy): imiti (pills), inkoni (implant), IUD, inshinge (injection/Depo), na condom. Mbere yo gutanga inama, ndashaka kubaza: Ufite indwara runaka? Ushaka uburyo buhora igihe kirekire cyangwa bwihuta? (Before advising, I want to ask: Do you have any health conditions? Do you want a long-term method or short-term?) Dufatanye turebe icyiza kuri wewe. (Let's work together to see what's best for you.) Urashobora kubaza mu Kinyarwanda cyangwa Icyongereza - byombi nibyo. (You can ask in Kinyarwanda or English - both are fine.)
responses.model_response:
Hari uburyo bwinshi bwo kuboneza urubyaro ushobora guhitamo, bitewe n’uko wifuza kubukoresha n’uko ubuzima bwawe buhagaze.  Dore ingero zimwe zigaragara mu mabwiriza ya WHO:   

• Agakingirizo k’abagabo cyangwa ak’abagore (Source 4).  
• Uburyo bwo kuboneza nyuma yo gukora imibonano “pills zo ku gitera gikwiye—emergency contraceptive pills” (Source 2).  
• Uburyo bwo kumenya iminsi fertile (fertility awareness methods) (Source 4).  
• “Withdrawal” (gukuramo igitsina mbere yo kurangiza) (Source 4).  
• Spermicides (Source 4).  
• Cervical cap cyangwa diaphragm (Source 4).  

Ibi buryo bisaba gukorwa neza buri gihe habayeho imibonano cyangwa kwirinda gukora imibonano ku minsi fertile; iyo bidakozwe neza bishobora kugabanuka ubushobozi bwo kurinda gusama (Source 4).  

Hari n’izindi nzira nyinshi zishobora kwifashishwa nka “self-care” (kwifasha ubwawe) zikaba zishobora gukoreshwa neza kandi mu mutekano (Source 3), ariko bisaba ko usobanukirwa neza uko zikoreshwa.  

Ku bw’ibyo:  
1. Tekereza ku byo wifuza (nko kudategereza igihe kirekire, kudasaba gufata buri munsi, n’ibindi).  
2. Kugira ngo ubone amakuru arambuye ku buryo bwose buhari n’uko bihuye n’amateka yawe y’ubuzima, byaba byiza uganiriye n’umukozi w’ishami ry’ubuzima cyangwa umujyanama w’Igihugu cy’Ubuzima. Bashobora no kuguha ako kanya agakingirizo n’ututi twihutirwa (emergency pills) niba ubyifuza (Source 2).  

Niba hari ibindi ukeneye kumenya ku buryo burenze uku, gerayo kwa muganga cyangwa ku kigo nderabuzima cyawe.

responses.scenario: Can a Community Health Worker (Animatrice) give me contraception, or do I need to go to the health center?
responses.ground_truth: Community Health Workers (Animatrices) in Rwanda can provide you with birth control pills and condoms, and they can counsel you on all contraceptive methods. However, for the implant, IUD, or Depo-Provera injection, you'll need to visit a health center or hospital where trained providers can insert or administer these methods. CHWs can help you understand your options and give you a referral if you want a method they can't provide. Both community-based and facility-based services are safe, effective, and free or low-cost. You can start by seeing your local CHW, and they'll guide you to the right place based on which method you choose.
responses.model_response:
The guidelines in the sources you gave do not spell out exactly which contraceptive methods Rwanda’s Community Health Workers (Animatrices) are authorised to provide. They only say that:

• Different “cadres of health workers” may offer family-planning services as long as they follow WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (Source 1).  
• Providers can give clients condoms, oral contraceptive pills and emergency contraceptive pills to take home (Source 4).

Because the documents do not list the specific tasks allowed for Animatrices, I cannot confirm whether your local CHW can start or refill the method you want. The safest approach is to:

1. Ask your Animatrice what methods she is trained and authorised to give.  
2. If she cannot provide the method you prefer, she should refer you to the nearest health centre, where all options are available.  
3. You can visit the health facility any time you have questions or need a method (Source 2).

If you are unsure, visiting the health centre will ensure you have access to the full range of contraceptive choices.

responses.scenario: I can't afford to pay for contraception. Are there free options in Rwanda?
responses.ground_truth: Contraception is free or very low-cost at public health facilities in Rwanda. All contraceptive methods - pills, implants, IUDs, Depo injections, condoms - are available at no cost or minimal cost at health centers and district hospitals. If you have Mutuelle de Santé (community health insurance), family planning services are covered. Even without insurance, contraception is provided free or at very low cost because the government prioritizes family planning access. You can visit any public health center, district hospital, or even see a Community Health Worker for some methods. Cost should not be a barrier - you have the right to access the contraceptive method that works best for you.
responses.model_response: I’m sorry, the information I have here does not say whether contraception is offered free of charge in Rwanda. It would be best to ask at your nearest health center, pharmacy, or talk with a qualified health-care provider to learn about any no-cost or low-cost family-planning services that may be available to you.

responses.scenario: I just had a baby at the health center. When will they talk to me about family planning?
responses.ground_truth: Congratulations on your baby! In Rwanda, family planning is integrated into maternal health services, so health providers will talk to you about family planning soon - often before you leave the health center or during your postnatal visits. Some methods like the IUD or implant can even be provided immediately after delivery (postplacental insertion) if you're interested. During your postnatal care visits, providers will discuss your options based on whether you're breastfeeding and your preferences. You don't have to wait - you can start planning for spacing your children right away. Providers will help you choose a method that's safe while breastfeeding and fits your family goals.
responses.model_response:
According to the World Health Organization Family Planning handbook:

• “Help pregnant women and new mothers decide how they will avoid pregnancy after childbirth. Ideally, family planning counseling should start during antenatal care.” (Source 3)

This means health-care staff are expected to begin the conversation during pregnancy. If it was not discussed then, they should raise it now—before you and your baby leave the health facility—and continue the discussion at your routine post-partum contacts (for example, the 6-week visit, when some women may choose to start a contraceptive method such as progestin-only pills; Source 1).

If no one has spoken with you yet, feel free to ask before discharge so you can get information and choose when and how to space your next pregnancy.

responses.scenario: Should I bring my husband with me when I go to get contraception?
responses.ground_truth: You can access contraception with or without your husband - the choice is yours. Rwanda's family planning program encourages partner involvement because discussing family planning together can strengthen couples' decisions. If you'd like to bring your husband, providers can offer couples counseling where you discuss options together. However, you don't need his permission or presence to access contraception. Providers respect your right to make your own decisions about your reproductive health. Some women prefer to discuss with their partners first, while others choose independently - both are completely acceptable. The most important thing is that you get the method that works best for you and your family goals.
responses.model_response:
It is entirely your choice.

• You can go alone. Family-planning services in Rwanda are available to women whether or not their partner is present.  
• If you feel comfortable, you may invite your husband to come with you. The guideline notes that “men can also use contraception” and “men should be active in parenting,” so some couples find it helpful to attend together, ask questions, and make a joint plan (Source 5, BCS Plus Toolkit, p. 232).  
• If your husband cannot or does not wish to come, you can still receive counselling and any method you choose on your own.

Bottom line: bring him only if you would like his presence and believe it will support your decision-making. Otherwise, you are welcome to visit the clinic by yourself.
